title: Maximum Sum Subarray of Size K
description: Given an array of positive numbers and a positive number 'k,' find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size 'k'.
aim: The goal is to introduce the sliding window technique and show how it improves over brute force for fixed-size subarray problems.

examples.explanation: Subarray [5, 1, 3] has the maximum sum of 9.
Subarray [3, 4] has the maximum sum of 7.

Now comes the revolutionary part of sliding window - instead of starting over with a new window, we'll 'slide' our existing window one position to the right. Imagine sliding a picture frame across a painting. We'll remove the leftmost element (2) and add a new rightmost element (1). Click on element at index 3 (value 1) to experience the sliding magic!

steps.codeSnippet:
// Slide the window efficiently
windowSum -= arr[windowStart]; // Remove left: 8 - 2 = 6
windowStart++;                  // Move start: 0 â†’ 1
windowEnd++;                    // Move end: 2 â†’ 3
windowSum += arr[windowEnd];    // Add right: 6 + 1 = 7
steps.codeExplanation: Here's the sliding window magic! Instead of recalculating the sum from scratch (slow), we efficiently update it: subtract the element leaving the window, then add the element entering the window. This transforms an O(nÃ—k) problem into O(n)!

// Slide and update maximum
windowSum -= arr[1];    // Remove: 7 - 1 = 6

steps.codeExplanation: The intuition of 'always remember the best' translates to Math.max() in code. Every time we slide the window, we compare the new sum with our best-so-far (maxSum). If the new window is better, we update our record. This ensures we never lose track of the optimal solution!

steps.codeExplanation:
The beautiful conclusion! Our intuition of 'keep track of the best' becomes a simple return statement. The maxSum variable has been our faithful companion, remembering the optimal solution throughout our journey. The algorithm efficiently found the answer in O(n) time instead of O(nÃ—k).

**Time Complexity (TC): O(n)** - We visit each element exactly once in our single loop. No nested loops means linear time!

**Space Complexity (SC): O(1)** - We only use a fixed number of variables (windowSum, maxSum, windowStart) regardless of input size. Constant space!

ðŸŽ¯ **Why this matters**: Sliding window transforms a naive O(nÃ—k) brute force approach into an elegant O(n) solution. For an array of 1000 elements with k=100, we go from 100,000 operations to just 1,000 operations - that's 100x faster!

bruteForce.idea: Check every subarray of size k, compute its sum, and track the maximum.
walkthrough: Iterate i from 0 to n - k.
For each i, compute windowSum by adding arr[i] to arr[i+k-1].

optimal.idea: Use a sliding window to maintain the sum of the last k elements and update in O(1) time as the window slides.
walkthrough: Build the first window of size k by summing the first k elements.
Slide the window forward by adding arr[end] and subtracting arr[start].
At each step, update maxSum if windowSum is larger.
Return maxSum after traversing the array.
